channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: What to Know About U.S.-Iran Nuclear Talks Amid Trump Threats
item.description: President Trump has kept up a steady drumbeat of threats and built up U.S. troops in the region. Iran’s task is to give him a win but also preserve some semblance of nuclear enrichment.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Omani Foreign Ministry, via Agence France-Presse
item.media:description: In this photo released by Oman’s Foreign Ministry, U.S. envoys, Steve Witkoff, center, and Jared Kushner, meet with the Omani foreign minister, Badr Albusaidi, in Geneva.

item.title: Venezuela’s Capital, Laid Low by Misrule, Is Stirring Back to Life
item.description: New restaurants are popping up in Caracas. Nightclubs are bursting at the seams. The streets are eerily safe — with big exceptions. Could a revival be on the horizon?
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Caracas “has the wages of Zimbabwe, the public services of Bangladesh and the prices of New York,” a political analyst said.

item.title: China Wants Germany in Its Corner. It’s Not That Easy.
item.description: China’s play for U.S. allies has a problem: As Germany’s leader showed, Europe’s grievances with Beijing may run deeper than its frustration with Trump.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz of Germany at the Forbidden City in Beijing on Thursday, the second day of a trip during which he promoted ties while airing German concerns about Chinese trade practices.

item.title: The Secret of How Ukraine’s Lifesaving Air-Raid Alarms Work
item.description: Many in Ukraine assume that the alerts are automated. A rare look inside an emergency-response center reveals the specialists who do the pressure-packed job.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Oleksandr Chubko
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alina Ustiuhova, a supervisor, left, with colleagues in a secret air-defense facility below ground in Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Russia Launches Big Strikes Before U.S.-Ukraine Talks in Geneva
item.description: Ukrainian officials said they hoped that trilateral peace negotiations could take place next week.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:description: An apartment building hit by a Russian strike in Zaporizhzhia, Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: German Intelligence Must Temporarily Halt an Extremist Label for the AfD, Court Rules
item.description: The domestic intelligence agency can still spy on the far-right party, and the ruling may not change Germans’ views, but it is a symbolic victory for the AfD.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Alternative für Deutschland, or AfD, in Halle, Germany, last year.

item.title: Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen Calls Snap Elections in Denmark
item.description: Experts say Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen is trying to capitalize on her success standing up to President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Regin Winther Poulsen
item.media:credit: Thomas Traasdahl/Ritzau Scanpix Foto, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark giving a speech about an upcoming parliamentary election in Copenhagen on Thursday.

item.title: Israeli Intelligence Agent Charged in Smuggling Goods Into Gaza
item.description: The indictment against an agent of the Shin Bet security agency added to a growing list of Israelis accused of exploiting their positions in the security forces to profit from the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer
item.media:description: The Erez crossing, one of the few official entry points used by Israel to control the flow of goods into the Gaza Strip, in 2024.

item.title: What We Know About the Gun Battle Off the Coast of Cuba
item.description: Four armed Cubans aboard a Florida-based speedboat died in a gunfight with Cuban border troops on Wednesday, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Frances Robles, Jack Nicas, Eric Schmitt and Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Cuban Coast Guard ships docked at the port of Havana on Wednesday.

item.title: Europe Needs Some Space From China and Trump. Its Firms Don’t.
item.description: Germany’s chancellor seeks to reduce Europe’s reliance on China and the United States. He speaks with a bluntness that few business leaders share.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz in Beijing on Wednesday with Premier Li Qiang.

item.title: How Israelis Feel About Another Potential War With Iran
item.description: The national mood is somewhere between anxiety, resignation and anticipation as President Trump considers whether to attack Iran.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: Near a bomb shelter in June during an Iranian missile attack in Rishpon, Israel. Israelis have been glued to the news recently as President Trump deliberates over whether to attack Iran.

item.title: One Nation, an Anti-Immigration Party in Australia, Rises in Polls After Bondi Massacre
item.description: Pauline Hanson and her One Nation party have become more palatable for some Australians after the mass shooting at Bondi Beach.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Darren England/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.media:description: Pauline Hanson, the leader of the One Nation party, at a rally in Brisbane, Australia, last month. She has long argued that Australia needs to curb what she calls “mass migration.”

item.title: President Emmanuel Macron’s Cultural Legacy At Risk After Louvre Chief Resigns
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron has championed a refurbishment of the museum, but the fallout from a sensational heist has put his plans at risk.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron giving a speech last year at the Louvre, in front of the Mona Lisa.

item.title: The Gorton and Denton By-Election Comes at a Bad Time for Keir Starmer
item.description: A parliamentary by-election in Gorton and Denton, outside Manchester, will test support for Britain’s prime minister at a moment of intense political pressure.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain at a Labour campaign event on Monday ahead of the Gorton and Denton by-election in Manchester, England.

item.title: Amid Rhetoric About Rupture With U.S., Finland Urges Calm
item.description: “We don’t need a bulldozer,” says Alexander Stubb, Finland’s president and a golf partner of President Trump. “Reform doesn’t mean destruction.”
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Saara Mansikkamaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Alexander Stubb of Finland, last year. Mr. Stubb says he recognizes that the world has changed, perhaps forever, and that Europe is not Washington’s priority.

item.title: With a New Nigeria Refinery, Africa’s Richest Man Wants ‘to Rescue the Country’
item.description: Aliko Dangote, Africa’s richest man, has an ambitious vision for the continent’s most populous nation, but hurdles stand in his way.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Victor Adewale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aliko Dangote at home in Lagos, Nigeria, last month.

item.title: Trump’s Foreign Policy: Resurrecting Empire
item.description: President Trump’s approach is a revival of the mission of empire — acquiring the territories and resources of sovereign peoples.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio, right, has been leading the Trump administration’s foreign policy.

item.title: Pakistan Strikes Afghanistan in ‘Open War’ Against Taliban Regime
item.description: The airstrikes came hours after Afghan troops had attacked Pakistani border positions and follow months of worsening relations between the neighboring countries.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Safiullah Padshah
item.media:description: The Afghan capital, Kabul. Pakistan bombed major cities in Afghanistan including Kabul on Friday.

item.title: Green Party Defeats Labour in U.K. Special Election, in Blow to Starmer
item.description: The result marks the first time the Greens have won a British parliamentary by-election and signals the frustration of left-leaning voters with Prime Minister Keir Starmer.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear
item.media:description: Hannah Spencer, who won a historic victory for the Green Party on Thursday, outside a polling station in the Gorton and Denton district outside Manchester.

item.title: Iranians Cite Progress in Talks, but a Marathon Session Produces No Deal
item.description: Representatives of the countries were in Geneva this week to discuss the fate of Iran’s nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: The U.S. special envoy Steve Witkoff, who, with Jared Kushner, Mr. Trump’s son-in-law, is negotiating with Iran’s foreign minister Abbas Araghchi.

item.title: After a Speedboat Shootout in Cuba, There are More Questions Than Answers
item.description: The Cuban government’s account of a supposed armed raid into its territory was called into question after one of the men identified as being on the boat turned up in Miami.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and Patricia Mazzei
item.media:description: Cuban coast guard ships docked at the Port of Havana on Thursday.

item.title: Will World Cup Games in Mexico Be Affected by Cartel Boss Killing?
item.description: Safety questions linger since the country is set to host matches in the world’s largest sporting event, the FIFA World Cup.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Cristopher Rogel Blanquet for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police officer patrolling the historic center of Mexico City on Monday.

item.title: 15 South Africans Duped Into Fighting for Russia in Ukraine Return Home
item.description: The South African leader said that the men had come home two weeks after he had won agreement from President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Zimasa Matiwane
item.media:description: South African men who said they had been duped into fighting for Russia after arriving in Durban, South Africa, on Wednesday.

item.title: Game-Changing Drugs
item.description: Ozempic and similar weight-loss medications are hailed as miracle drugs. But there are plenty of unknowns about long-term use.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times

item.title: What Your DNA Reveals About the Sex Life of Neanderthals
item.description: Most people alive today carry fragments of Neanderthal DNA in their genome. Now scientists are gaining a more intimate understanding of the ancient encounters that put it there.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: An artist’s rendering of a human skull, at left, and a Neanderthal skull. Most people alive today carry a bit of Neanderthal DNA in their genome, the result of interbreeding tens of thousands of years ago.

item.title: Why U.S. Allies Are Lining Up to Meet China
item.description: Amid trade disputes with President Trump, leaders of major U.S. allies have been visiting China. Our foreign correspondent David Pierson describes what’s going on.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Leila Medina, Shawn Paik and James Surdam

item.title: Family of U.N. Expert Critical of Israel Sues Trump Over Sanctions
item.description: The family of Francesca Albanese, a critic of Israel’s war in Gaza, asked a court to void the Trump administration’s sanctions against her.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: The family of Francesca Albanese sued the Trump administration over its imposition of sanctions against her.

item.title: They Helped Women Fight Online Abuse. They Were Barred From the U.S.
item.description: The founders of HateAid, a German human-rights group that helps victims of online attacks, were accused by the Trump administration of being part of a “global censorship-industrial complex.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Patrick Junker
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna-Lena von Hodenberg, left, and Josephine Ballon, right, of the organization HateAid. The group provides legal support for victims of digital violence and engages in policy advocacy aimed at strengthening accountability for major online platforms.

item.title: The Latest New Zealander to Move to Australia Is an Ex-Prime Minister
item.description: Jacinda Ardern, New Zealand’s former leader, is basing her family in Australia “for the moment,” a spokesman said. She is part of a wave of Kiwis relocating to their larger neighbor.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Lauren O'Neil for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jacinda Ardern, the former prime minister of New Zealand. Her family “has been traveling for a few years now,” and would be based in Australia for the time being, a spokesman said.

item.title: A Japanese City Received 21 Gold Bars With Instructions: Fix Your Water Pipes
item.description: An anonymous donation of $3.6 million worth of gold highlights frustration with Osaka’s aging waterworks. It will only finance repairs to a fraction of the pipes that need to be replaced.
item.dc:creator: Francesca Regalado and Kiuko Notoya

item.title: North Korea’s ​Kim Jong-un Hints at Improving U.S. Relations — With Caveats
item.description: ​ The North Korean leader said that his country can get along well with the United States as long as Washington accepts it as a nuclear weapons state.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A news broadcast in Seoul on Thursday showing footage of Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, speaking at the ruling Workers’ Party congress.

item.title: Vessels Have Clashed With Cuban Border Forces Before
item.description: On Wednesday, a Florida-registered speedboat entered Cuban waters and some on board exchanged gunfire with Cuban troops. Two such armed clashes occurred in 2022.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:description: In 2022, Cuba’s Ministry of Interior announced that it had intercepted a total of 13 speedboats engaged in migrant-smuggling that year. They also intercepted other vessels, like the one above on Dec. 12 of that year.

item.title: Antonio Tejero Molina, 93, Dies; Spanish Colonel Led Failed Coup
item.description: He held Spain’s Parliament hostage for 18 hours on Feb. 23, 1981, before surrendering after it became clear that he had little support from the country’s armed forces.
item.dc:creator: Alan Cowell
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.media:description: Antonio Tejero Molina on Feb. 23, 1981, the day he led a takeover of the Parliament in Spain as part of an attempted coup.

item.title: Why South Korea’s Dubai Chewy Cookie Craze Rose and Fell So Fast
item.description: The brief life span of the Dubai chewy cookie reflects the country’s fast-moving food trends, where hype often matters more than taste.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: The dujjonku is a variation of Dubai chocolate, bars filled with pistachio cream and shredded phyllo known as kataifi, which became a global sensation in early 2025.

item.title: Greek Politician Is Prosecuted for Admitting Drug Use Decades Ago
item.description: The leftist party of Yanis Varoufakis, a former finance minister and critic of the conservative government, said he had been charged based on admitting he had tried ecstasy once.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni and Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yanis Varoufakis in 2015. He faces prosecution for admitting to using ecstasy 36 years ago.

item.title: Inside Tapalpa, the Town in Mexico Where El Mencho Made His Last Stand
item.description: Times reporters visiting Tapalpa found a serene town in shock after Sunday’s raid on its outskirts left dozens dead and people fleeing. And, surprisingly, no police or military presence where the battle took place.
item.dc:creator: Paulina Villegas and César Rodríguez
item.media:credit: César Rodríguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town of Tapalpa, in Jalisco state, Mexico, is a stronghold of the Jalisco New Generation Cartel.

item.title: A Last Chance Before War
item.description: The U.S. and Iran both say they want to avoid a conflict. Time is running out to avoid one.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A march on the anniversary of the 1979 Islamic revolution in Tehran this month.

item.title: U.S. Will Offer Embassy Services in a West Bank Settlement for the First Time
item.description: Palestinians and Israelis on the right and left all say that the move is a step toward legitimizing the Israeli settlements, which most of the world considers illegal.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:description: The Israeli settlement of Efrat in the Israeli-occupied West Bank in 2020. The U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem says it will provide passport assistance in Efrat on Friday.

item.title: Trump’s speech gets a mixed reaction around the world.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: President Trump delivering his State of the Union address in Washington on Tuesday.

item.title: Cuban Government Kills 4 in Gunfire Exchange Aboard Florida Speedboat
item.description: Four people aboard a Florida-based speedboat died in a gunfight with Cuban border troops near the island nation’s coast, the Cuban Interior Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Frances Robles, Jack Nicas and Eric Schmitt

item.title: Brazil’s Supreme Court Convicts Four Men in Murder of Marielle Franco
item.description: Two politicians and two former police officers were found guilty in the assassination of a rival, Marielle Franco, a Rio de Janeiro city councilwoman who fought corruption and violence.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova
item.media:credit: Renan Olaz/Rio De Janeiro Municipal Chamber
item.media:description: Marielle Franco, a member of Rio de Janeiro’s City Council, leading a session in 2017 at the municipal chamber in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: BBC and BAFTA Say They Are Investigating After Broadcast of Racist Slur
item.description: The awards organization and the broadcaster have ordered separate investigations into what led to airing the slur, which was shouted involuntarily during Sunday’s ceremony.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.category: British Academy of Film and Television
item.media:description: The actors Michael B. Jordan and Delroy Lindo were onstage at the BAFTA Awards when a racist slur was involuntarily shouted by a man with Tourette’s syndrome.

item.title: 45 Years After Failed Coup, Spain Declassifies Files About Why It Failed
item.description: Ending more than four decades of conjecture, the Spanish government moved to publish documents from a long-secret investigation of a failed 1981 coup.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Lt. Col. Antonio Tejero Molina, with a pistol in his hand, attempting a coup at the Spanish Parliament on Feb. 23, 1981.

item.title: How the UK Could Remove Former Prince Andrew From the Royal Line of Succession
item.description: Despite his connections with the sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, the former prince is eighth in line to the British throne. That could change.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom

item.title: Pope Leo to Visit Africa, Signaling Continent’s Importance to Catholicism
item.description: The number of Roman Catholics is growing faster in Africa than anywhere else, according to the Vatican.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Leo XIV in Turkey in November, during his first trip abroad as pontiff.

item.title: Germany’s Leader Merz Delivers a Blunt Warning to China on Trade
item.description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz laid out his complaints in a frank message to his hosts on a trip to Beijing that China had designed to showcase their relationship.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Jim Tankersley
item.category: Great Hall of the People (Beijing, China)
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China greets Chancellor Friedrich Merz of Germany ahead of their meeting at the Diaoyutai State Guesthouse in Beijing on Wednesday.

item.title: A Seasoned French Museum Chief Takes Over a Louvre in Crisis
item.description: Christophe Leribault, who runs the Palace of Versailles, will replace Laurence des Cars, who resigned months after an audacious jewel heist.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Christophe Leribault was the deputy director of the Louvre’s graphic arts department from 2006 to 2012 and has run three other museums, in addition to the one at Versailles.

item.title: Thanks, Ukrainians Say, but Please Stop Calling Us Resilient
item.description: Ukraine must project strength to secure continued Western support. But its people want the world to know they are not superhuman.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Oksana Parafeniuk
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times

item.title: Inside Nicolás Maduro’s Last Days as Venezuela’s Leader
item.description: The Venezuelan leader overestimated his strength and misread his exchange with President Trump in the decisive weeks before his capture by U.S. forces.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Mariana Martínez and Tyler Pager
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: In his final weeks in power, President Nicolás Maduro still believed a deal with Washington was possible, people close to him said.

item.title: Ukraine Wants to Join the E.U. to Secure Peace. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Negotiators agree that joining the bloc is critical to Kyiv’s future. But obstacles abound, and compromises might forever change how the union works.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:description: From left, António Costa, president of the European Council; President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine; and Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, in Brussels last year.

item.title: Former Prince Andrew’s Arrest Is Met With Strong Reactions and Apathy in Windsor
item.description: “Her children have let her down,” said one woman, referring to Queen Elizabeth II. Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor’s fall from grace drew strong reactions from some. Others said they just did not care.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Stephen Castle
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Queen Elizabeth II and members of the royal family at Buckingham Palace, in 2019.

item.title: Futsal Phenom in Afghanistan Is a Hero the Taliban Didn’t Expect
item.description: A triumph in indoor soccer has turned Alireza Ahmadi, 17, and other players from the Hazara minority, long marginalized in Afghanistan, into national heroes.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier, Yaqoob Akbary and Tomás Munita
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times

item.title: Same War, Different Message: Trump Tonight vs. Biden Four Years Ago
item.description: President Trump issued no statement in support of Ukraine on the anniversary of the Russian invasion, four years after his predecessor laid out the stakes.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hundreds of Ukrainian soldiers’ graves in Lviv, Ukraine, on Tuesday.

item.title: Trump Squeezes Cuba
item.description: Many U.S. presidents have tried to bring down the Communist government over almost seven decades. This time, it feels different.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: A blackout in Havana, Cuba, on Saturday.

item.title: Study Shows Xi’s Purges of China’s Military Run Deep
item.description: Around 100 senior officers have been sidelined or vanished since 2022, hollowing out the top ranks and raising questions about the army’s capabilities.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Gen. Zhang Youxia, who was vice chairman of the Central Military Commission at the time, waving at the Western Pacific Naval Symposium in Qingdao, China, in 2024.

item.title: What to Know About the Cartels Operating in Mexico
item.description: Other criminal groups in Mexico may try to take advantage of the death of Nemesio Oseguera Cervantes, also known as El Mencho, who ran the Jalisco New Generation Cartel.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Offerings of flowers, candles, photos and dollar bills at a shrine to Jesús Malverde — a “narco-saint,” in Culiacán, Sinaloa state, in 2024.

item.title: Louvre Director Resigns, Months After Crown Jewels Were Stolen in Heist
item.description: Laurence des Cars’s departure is the latest setback for the world’s largest museum. Her tenure was marred by labor strikes, water leaks, a ticket scam and security lapses, which led to the heist in October.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Laurence des Cars, the president and director of the Louvre Museum, during a hearing at the National Assembly in Paris last year.

item.title: Germany’s Leader Heads to China and Walks a Tightrope Between Xi and Trump
item.description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s trip will test his ability to address tensions between the countries, at a time of strain between Europe and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley and David Pierson
item.media:description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz of Germany arriving at a meeting at the White House last year. Mr. Merz will visit China for the first time since he became chancellor last May, testing his ability to balance ties between Berlin and Beijing.

item.title: Ukraine Battlefield Dead Could Reach 500,000 in Fifth Year, Estimates Suggest
item.description: Russia has lost as many as 325,000 troops, according to some estimates, with more than 200,000 deaths verified by researchers.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne and Constant Méheut
item.category: Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians carrying the body of a Russian soldier near a destroyed Russian border post in 2024.
